response.answer_text: I absolutely think programming/scripting should be taught in school, and I even think it should be a mandatory subject. However, I do not believe software engineering should be taught in school, except as an elective. That’s a leap I’ve seen people make. I don’t think we should try to force students to learn how to write the next big app or awesome server-side startup in high school. (As an elective, go for it, but don’t force it.) So how exactly do we do that? I honestly don’t know, but I do have some personal feelings: You should start in grade school with “Scratch” or similar. Focusing on fun little games, and build towards a real “project” at the end of grade school. Let them show off those projects to the younger kids!In middle-school, shift the focus to a REPL-capable language, but keep the overall structure similar. Mix in some computing fundamentals (RAM vs HDD vs SSD) and light history. Include I/O. Build again towards a project at the end of middle-school that incorporates everything.In high-school is when you can dip into meaningful distinctions between collections, some light theory, discussion of algorithmic complexity, functional techniques, recursion, utilizing multiple CPUs and why that’s hard but important.Optional courses starting in high-school can explore specific niches like Software Engineering, Machine Learning, App Development, Web Development, etc. all with the goal of giving enough of a taste to help students decide if they want to pursue that topic more thoroughly.Computers are particularly cool because they mix the intellectual rigour of subjects like Math with the enjoyment students get out of doing something real in a hands-on way, like an Art or Industrial Arts class. In Math, you learn how to do problems, but it’s not clear how that ever could be useful. That’s the reason most of my classmates hated it. In Computers, you learn how to make something that solves problems for you, and can actually make something you enjoy like a game. Then in High School you shift the conversation towards the massive potential that computers have locked within them. We have watches more powerful than mainframes used to be - how do I access that instead of just treating it like a toaster with a “go” button? Of course, therein lies the hardest problem - how do you keep course-content relevant? How much more powerful will computers be in 5–10 years? It’ll require a much more fluid approach than most classes we teach today.

As the son of a teacher and a systems engineer I can claim to be genetically qualified to answer. My real qualification is that I've raised two children to adulthood and I did try to teach them something about programming when they were in grade / primary school.  First, be aware that: Not every kid is going to be interested in programming.  You want an approach that will be of interest to a wide range of personalities.  You want them to take something positive away from the experience, even if they aren't the next John Carmack.[1]Children have limited attention spans and quickly lose interest in dry material.  The more you can make programming seem like playing a game, the better.[2]You don't want to rush with brains that are immature - for example, at 11, males may be less than halfway to their peak brain volume! [3] But it's a great time to teach because 11 year olds are approaching the second of their peaks in neuroplasticity.Bearing all of this and more in mind, when the time comes for "hands-on programming", the ESSENTIAL experience for kids is "Scratch" from MIT.  See scratch.mit.edu or see the review in the New York Times.[4] One of Scratch's strengths is that it  combines teaching with play in an environment that is highly creative and  can accommodate silliness.  If the experience is fun, there's more chance children will experiment with it when they're on their own or with their friends. A friend of mine has produced a stepping stone for kids who outgrow Scratch but are not quite ready for a grown-up language. A key feature is mobile support. A lot of people have mentioned some really great resources here already. Obviously, there’s no one single resource just yet that’s THE BEST way to teach a kid to program, so you have to be involved and inventive. When you’re teaching a kid to program, the two most important things are: Keep it fun. If it’s not fun, they will resent the process, won’t want to keep doing it, and their ability to learn how to program will be compromised.Assess their skill constantly. This point isn’t as obvious but it’s absolutely critical. Let me break down why this is so important by starting with the concept of flow.Flow and Game Design Flow is that wonderful state of feeling fully immersed in what you’re working on. You’re able to focus, feel involved, and enjoy what you’re working on. If you can keep kids in a state of flow, without making it too easy or too hard, then they’ll stay engaged and learning will feel fun. Flow is a core idea in game design, because a game needs to keep users in this state in order to keep them engaged and interested long-term.  This graph shows how narrow the flow zone actually is. In the lowest quadrant of the graph, where difficulty is low, it doesn’t matter if your child’s skill level is also low. But as the material becomes more difficult, it’s easy to get off track. If the learner’s skill progresses faster than the difficulty of the material does, then they’ll get bored, but if the material gets too hard for them before their skill catches up, they become anxious and begin to dislike the process. Since being in a state of flow is fundamentally motivational, this is really the key to making sure that a child actually learns and remains interested in the learning process. How do you ensure that a child stays in a state of flow as they learn how to program? That’s where mastery learning comes into play. Mastery Learning Mastery learning is an educational philosophy popularized by the influential educational psychologist Benjamin Bloom. The idea is that a student must prove that they have mastered a skill or concept before they can progress to the next level. If they haven’t reached at least 90% comprehension when they’re assessed, they are given additional instruction and practice until they hit that benchmark. One-on-one instruction, rather than the traditional classroom structure, is a key component to mastery learning, since no two students learn at the same speed or will ever be at the exact same place in the flow zone. Bloom proved in his 2 sigma problem that an average child who is individually tutored using mastery learning techniques will perform 2 standard deviations above average, compared to children educated in a traditional classroom. (One of the only true implementations of this philosophy right now is Kumon, an international chain of schools that teach math and language skills. At a Kumon school, there is no one curriculum that every student follows. Instead, teachers create individual learning plans for each student, which are updated regularly based on the student’s progress. A student can’t move on to new material until they prove that they’ve mastered the material they are currently studying.) Assessment As you can see, the ability to constantly assess someone’s ability in a very precise manner is the key to keeping them engaged and in the state of flow. No standardized, non-responsive learning experience can replicate mastery learning’s individualized assessment techniques. There’s not a perfect tutorial or app on the market right now because automated assessment hasn’t been truly perfected yet. In most cases, kids using one of these tools will fall out of the flow state either because the material gets too hard and they don’t want to do it anymore or it’s not hard enough and they get bored. We at CodeFights have made a lot of headway in automated assessments in the past few years, but our focus is still on the top end of the learning spectrum. When it comes to early stage learning, for now, manual assessment is the only true way to accurately keep tabs on a child’s skill level and to keep them engaged in the learning process. This means that you have to be vigilant about testing their mastery level, adjusting the material they’re learning so that it’s in line with their skills. That way, they are able to constantly stay in the flow zone and the process stays fun. While the process of using mastery learning principles and constant assessment to keep a child who’s learning to program in a state of flow will take a lot more effort on your part than just plopping them in front of a browser with Scratch loaded up, it will pay off in the end. The child will remain engaged in the learning process and will be highly motivated to keep “leveling up”. As a former software engineer myself and a homeschool mom, I have had quite a journey in teaching my kids to code. To answer this question, I would split the question to 2 parts. 1. Kids who are less than 9-10 years old These kids are not very comfortable with reading yet. Their motor skills are not well developed to enable them to type well. So, what is recommended typically is using some block based coding applications. Scratch and Learn computer science. Change the world. are some popular websites which use block based coding. While these websites build the logical ability of the kid, I would still consider them more like Math 2.0 rather than coding itself. These websites spend a lot of time on some foundational concepts in computer programming. They have some game based and fun exercises teaching variables, conditional statements, loops etc. I engaged my kids also quite a lot in this during their younger years. Their favorite website was Learn computer science. Change the world. What I learnt though is that these activities majorly contribute to building the cognitive skills and can be at best considered as Math 2.0, not coding. Programming is much more than just logic. Programming is the ability to talk to computers and think from the computer's point of view. It also includes familiarity with the history of how it evolved. It means the knowledge of the environment, networks, OS and much more. So, unless the child takes up to computers intuitively and explores on his own, it is very difficult to teach programming to him at this age. 2. Kids who are more than 9-10 years old This is probably where text based coding can be introduced to the kids. There are different schools of thought when it comes to this. Some people say python is probably the best place to start along with solving programming challenges. I feel this school of thought does not consider what the kid wants. Most of my fellow parents who subscribe to this school of thought also want their kids to become competitive coders yesterday. More often than not, this pressure has resulted in the kids losing interest in coding itself. My take is they should start with web development - html, css and javascript. This means the focus is more on expressing themselves through code rather than making it more like math. They can create fun websites and games. They can relate it to their real life - maybe create a quiz app to be used by their teacher or an e-greeting card for their friend. Use mac to Create Something Fun Marius, Lucas, Lambert, Ethan, Andy, Peter, Grace, Elaine, Angie and Hal, ranging from grade 3 to grade 7, live in different places of the world. They are all my “close”, in the sense of “connected over internet”, friends, and enjoy building fun things on mac with their math and logic skills. They even push their code onto GibHub regularly like professionals. If they can do it so can your kids. You SHOULD NOT teach them too much of coding. The focus is on problem solving, reasoning, math skill, etc. instead of programming language itself. Set up a working environment, not much work actually, then you can start tackling math problems like “how to centre a grid inside the larger rectangle”, “how to convert screen coordinates (123.0, 234.0) to logical coordinates (3, 5) of chess board” or “what features I want to add into my apps”. Let me show you some examples first. Ethan made his first app without writing a single line of code. If all you have is a hammer, everything looks like a nail. Ethan had only “rectangle”.  Marius loves chess so much. He was so eager to build his own app to play with.  Lucas used an image of a piece to show whose turn.  Lambert had a much deeper understanding of coordinates system after drawing a game board.  Andy created a 14x14 gomoku board. He had to figure out how to centre the grid using his mathematical still. A simple for loop is needed to simplify horizontal lines and vertical lines.  Peter implemented connect 4 within a few days, completely on his own.  Grace added 2 text fields to save 24 game points for both players.  Elaine would play her snake game using 4 buttons.  Angie tried some circles after drawing lines. Letting each circle sit at right intersection turned out to be a small challenge to her.  Hal wrote tons of unit test cases to straighten out tricky logic of each rotation of layers in Rubik’s cube.  Indexing 54 squares is not a small challenge to Peter.  Grace has a good sense of 2-D layout.  Sometimes they are just kidding.  Huge pieces  or normal ones,  everything is under our control. The big takeaway is that we only care about how to draw a perfect game board, how to centre the board on screen based on calculation instead of guessing, how to draw lines or shapes efficiently, how to sit each piece at its exact location, how to determine which colour square goes where when the Rubik’s cube turns, ..., but NOT the computer, the programming language, the syntax etc.

I used to teach programming to children between the ages of 11 and 17 at a summer program at MIT (hooray for jobs which pay for college).  For those kids it was never as much about the tools which they used to program but in getting their attention on a project which they will really love.  One of the most successful ways to do this was to have them program a little RPG game.  First just do it with if statements where it reads from the command line a one line command and selects which branch to follow.  Then eventually the child will ask for items or begin the highly intensive process of trying to make something which resembles a physical map using only if statements.  This is a good time to introduce objects/structs/whatever.  Finally you can introduce libraries when they ask to do things like display pictures.  After this they normally have the basic idea and it is just about supporting them through interesting projects (and occassionally suggesting some when they run out) and teaching them important constructs along the way.  Have a whole bunch of projects, and don't be upset if the kid doesn't like your first project suggestion. Another rather popular tactic for the high school crowd is to teach them how to program their graphing calculators.  A good intro to this is something as simple as a fake basic screen which will give them the wrong answers when they try to calculate math problems. My first thought is this: If he is going along fine and hasn’t learned programming yet, he may just not like programming. It depends how old he is. If he has never been exposed to it, we don’t know if he will like it. If he is in high school, I’d say the odds are good that he just doesn’t have much interest. He has seen it around and hasn’t gravitated towards it. It’s just not his thing and forcing him will never work with such a mentally demanding hobby. Programming is a mentally challenging activity, but it is also a creative activity. It is something like doing math problems with art supplies … or making artwork with math supplies … something like that. It takes an eye for design, a feel for efficiency, an intuition for algorithms, fairly sharp math skills, and a brain that can hold a model of an idea very clearly and mold it like clay. It isn’t for everyone. If your son is young, like 5 or 6, then you are at the perfect time. His curiosity will never be so fresh and unspoiled. My dad just bought a computer, showed me a few programs, and gave me a book. I was about 6 years old and I just loved it. I learned how to read this difficult book. I copied other programs. I changed them and learned on my own how they worked. I had extremely limited resources (like 2 books … one on BASIC and one on DOS), nobody in the world to ask, no website to look at, no forums … nothing. And my dad was the type who just left me with those 2 books and let me figure it out. Later, he brought home some books about databases, C compilers, MASM, and Pascal. I went to the library and bookstore and ended up finding a book about computer graphics. I learned about projections and matrix translations and all sorts of crazy stuff by the time I was 10. So it is a great way to learn … but it takes tremendous focus and causes terrible frustration. But this was in the 1970s. Things are so much easier now. The main problem now is that there is too much information and a great deal of it is foisted on us by people who do not know what they are talking about. If you are a programmer, you will know the good YouTube channels. YouTube is a godsend for anyone learning anything!! It is much more efficient than books when you are trying to get past the beginning stages of learning that are so agonizing. It is just painful when you know so little that you can’t even figure out the words to Google a subject! Podcasts are great if you wan’t to learn while exercising or driving or just doing other stuff. Most of the coding “academies” are geared towards adults and i doubt a kid would enjoy the ones I’ve seen. From a teacher perspective, I think Khan Academy is very good. The main thing is to do your research. Read blog posts, watch a few YouTube videos with your son, check out local coding / robotics / drone building clubs. That is where the other computer nerds hang out. IMO, avoid video games as much as possible. They are horrible time sucks and the little bit you might accidentally learn is completely offset by the huge waste of time and brain atrophy. The best way to understand something is to break it and put it back together a different way.

First, start with drag and drop. This is very important since it teaches kids the principles of control flow, types, and thinking about abstract concepts as instruction sequences. Choose a good one, too, like Scratch. Second, start teaching them Python or JavaScript. These are good beginner's languages, where they don't (fully) have to worry about types. Python is especially good, because it cements the concept of proper indentation (as in, more than an optional to be applied later). Finish with a decently sized project for a beginner, such as a calculator. Third, begin a statically typed, strongly typed language that is more complex than what they've been working with, but not completely off the deep end. If your end goal is high-level, use Kotlin; if your end goal is low-level, use Rust. Make sure you know whichever language you're choosing before you teach it. Again, finish off with a project. The whole way: Explain every concept before you use it, explain not only what, but also how and why. Students should never feel like they are copying down what you said without understanding it.For that matter, impress upon them that if any student doesn't understand something, no matter how silly, they must, MUST seek help from you if they can't figure it out. Even the quiet students. Because they need to understand what they're doing and why, so they can break down the individual principles and concepts and reapply them. At no point do you ever want programming by superstition.Make sure they use good formatting. If you implement multiple projects, add a smallish point section to them for formatting. Best to nip this in the bud early.Use good editors. For Kotlin, only IntelliJ IDEA is acceptable. If you use Python, try to get an educational license for PyCharm; if JavaScript, do the same for WebStorm. There isn't a good JetBrains IDE for Rust, so if you go down that path I would say VSCode with the Rust plugin (not RustyCode) installed.Make sure to take enough time. Programming is slow learning the first part, and takes a while to speed up.There's probably more, but I can't think of them. Happy teaching!

They already understand math, so teach them conditional statements and write short loops that they can practice with on paper first. When I got to college, they started us out on Matlab. It was nice because the compiler was built in and the language is very forgiving.  You didn't need to write functions and pass variables, you could just type a line of code and it return the results without need for you to learn output syntax.Make each lesson produce something useful.  The thing that bugged me most was that when I started, I didn't want to learn how to make the computer just say "Hello World." I wanted to solve some problem or calculate the number of lego bricks in my castle, haha.  Find a way to show them the real world problems they could solve if they learn to code.Teach them to Google.  I eventually quit buying the books because now you can use Google and Stack Overflow to find just about anything you need to know.  This is by far the most useful tool in the modern programmer's toolbox because even if you code great in one language, you're bound to have to learn another at some point.

3 Tips to Teach Your child How to Read By: children reading and learning Learning to read at a young age is important for the development of the child. It helps them develop a better understand of their surroundings, allows them to gather information from printed materials, and provides them with a wonderful source of entertainment when they read stories and rhymes. Children develop at different rates, and some children will develop reading skills quicker than other children; however, what's important is that as the parent, you are keenly aware of your child's maturity and reading level to provide them with appropriate books and activities to help them improve. As parents, you are the most important teacher for your children. You will introduce your child to books and reading. Below we have some tips to help you teach your child to read. children reading and learning Teach Your Child How to Read Tip #1 Teach your child alphabet letters and sounds at the same time. Studies have shown that children learn best when they are taught the letter names and letter sounds at the same time. In one study, 58 preschool children were randomly assigned to receive instructions in letter names and sounds, letter sound only, or numbers (control group). The results of this study are consistent with past research results in that it found children receiving letter name and sound instruction were most likely to learn the sounds of letters whose names included cues to their sounds. When teaching your child the letter sounds, have them slowly trace the letter, while saying the sound of the letter at the same time. For example, if you were teaching your child the letter "A", you would say: "The letter A makes the /A/ (ah) sound." I can’t say I’ve ever tried to teach a child about programming, but I think that a good place to start would be to teach them about true/false statements. Is the sky blue? (your kid should look up. Is the sky blue or the dog’s name barky mcbarkface? Yes (or true) because the sky is blue today. How about “is the sky blue AND the dog’s name barky mcbarkface?” Instinctively they’ll answer no, as I’ve seen many times. Ask them to explain why the first thing (the OR) is true, and not the second (the AND). Try to get them to say something in the vein of “because for the ‘or’ only one needs to be true, but for the ‘and’ both need to be true.” To me that’s really the basis of programming is logic and control structures. Teaching Kids (of all ages) to Program We take a different approach to teaching folks how to program here at the Osmosian Order of Plain English Programmers. The Osmosian Order of Plain English Programmers Welcomes You The Interface The first thing we do is remove all unnecessary and distracting clutter. This, for example, is what our full-screen Integrated Development Environment (IDE) looks like:  Alphabetical menus and a status message field at the top, work area in the middle, and tabs at the bottom. No window borders, no widgets, no icons, no tool bars, and no palettes. We thus encourage the student to focus on the content in the foreground, not the background (which we leave in the background where it belongs). Whoops! Almost forgot. No scroll bars. Ever. The right mouse button is used to shove content around — horizontally, vertically, and/or diagonally — and an Incremental Find facility is used to “leap” in large files (ala the late, great Jef Raskin). The Home, End, Page Up, Page Down and Arrow keys are also used, intuitively, to change the focus as necessary. The file system is exposed to the programmer using full path names. This is the only view the programmer is given: there are no icons, and no alternate views in “open” and “save as” dialog boxes (because we don’t use or need dialog boxes). The students are thus introduced to the exact syntax that they will need to reference files in their programs, and they only have to maintain a single mental image of the file system in their budding brains. Our student’s applications are also clutter-free. When they clear the screen, it is erased to black, top-to-bottom and side-to-side. Their applications are real, native programs, with access to the whole screen (and computer), so their dreams can come to life exactly as they imagined them. No sandboxes. The Language The second difference in our approach is that we program in natural, English-language sentences. Our “keywords” are articles (like a, an, the and some), and prepositions (like in, of and with, etc) rather than obscure words like CONST and EVAL and INSTANCEOF (which, technically, aren’t real words at all). We also make a point of concentrating on semantics (WHAT is being said) rather than syntax (HOW it is being said). Routines in Plain English typically have multiple headers so they can be called in various ways. This routine, for example… To erase the screen;To blank out the screen;To wipe off the screen;To clear the screen:Unmask everything.Draw the screen’s box with the black color and the black color.Refresh the screen.Put the screen’s box into the context’s box. …can be called four different ways: Erase the screen.Blank out the screen.Wipe off the screen.Clear the screen. The skilled teacher, familiar with the way his students normally speak, typically provides pre-coded libraries of commonly used routines with headers in the “local dialect.” Students are also encouraged to teach the compiler to speak (and think) as they do, by adding headers to existing libraries, and by developing libraries of their own. The Depth The third difference in our approach is that we we use the same interface and language for both novices and experts alike. This is a system for kids, but it isn’t just a system for kids. We used this very interface and language ourselves to conveniently and efficiently create the whole shebang: uncluttered desktop, simplified file manager, elegant text editor, handy hexadecimal dumper, native-code-generating compiler/linker, and wysiwyg page layout facility for documentation and other creative writing and drawing tasks. So when the student is ready to dig deeper, he can simply dig. He doesn’t have to invest in a new shovel or find another plot of land. It’s all in one place, from “Hello, World!” to the machine code. Hello World! Speaking of “Hello, World!”, this is a version we often use to illustrate the fundamental concepts of sequence, conditional statements, and looping. This is what we tell the students to type in: To run:Start up.Clear the screen.Use medium letters. Use the fat pen.Pick a really dark color.Loop.Start in the center of the screen.Turn left 1/32 of the way.Turn right. Move 2 inches. Turn left.Write “HELLO WORLD”.Refresh the screen.Lighten the current color about 20 percent.Add 1 to a count. If the count is 32, break.Repeat.Wait for the escape key.Shut down. And this is what they see on the screen when they run their programs (using the Run command, which is conveniently and intuitively located under the “R” menu):  Desert Landscapes Programming is a textual, left-brain kind of activity. But students learn best when both sides of their brains are engaged. So most of our introductory exercises produce inspiring, graphical outputs to enliven both hemispheres and the corpus callosum that connects them. Here’s another sample program: To run:Start up.Draw a desert landscape.Wait for the escape key.Shut down. To draw a desert landscape:Clear the screen.Draw the sky.Draw the sun.Draw the birds.Draw the sand. To draw the sky:Use the lightest sky blue pen.Imagine a line across the middle of the screen’s box.Loop.Draw the line.Refresh the screen.Darken the current color about 3 percent.Move the line up 1 pixel.If the line is above the screen’s box’s top, break.Repeat. To draw the sun:Pick a spot anywhere in the top middle 1/4 of the screen’s box.Make a dot between 1/4 inch and 1 inch wide.Center the dot on the spot.Draw the dot with the lightest yellow color. To draw the birds:Pick a spot in the screen’s box about 1 inch above the middle.Use the black pen.Loop.Move to the spot.Face east.Pick a width between 1/8 inch and 1/4 inch.Draw a quarter circle given the width.Turn around.Draw another quarter circle given the width.Move the spot about 1/2 inch in any direction.Add 1 to a count. If the count is 3, break.Repeat. To draw the sand:Use the lightest orange pen.Imagine a line across the middle of the screen’s box.Loop.Draw the line.Refresh the screen.Darken the current color about 3 percent.Move the line down 1 pixel.If the line is below the screen’s box’s bottom, break.Repeat. Note the seamless integration of vector graphics and turtle graphics. Here’s the kind of artwork that program produces:  Optical Illusions Optical illusions are always fun and inspiring. This is one of my personal favorites: To run:Start up.Draw the crooked line illusion.Wait for the escape key.Shut down. To draw the crooked line illusion:Clear the screen.Use the fat pen.Imagine a big box 4 inches smaller than the screen’s box.Imagine a line across the top of the big box.Imagine a small box 1/2 inch by 1/2 inch.Move the small box to the top left corner of the big box.Loop.Draw and fill the small box with the white color.Move the small box right 1 inch.Refresh the screen.If the small box is still in the big box, repeat.Move the small box close to the left side of the big box.Draw the line with the red color.Move the line down 1/2 inch.Move the small box down 1/2 inch.If the small box is still in the big box, repeat.Draw the line with the red color.Use medium letters.Write “THE RED LINES ARE ALL STRAIGHT AND PARALLEL.”with the gold pen at the bottom of the screen’s box.Refresh the screen. You’re going to need a ruler to check out this result:  One More Thing This is the advice we give to our teachers: TEACHING IS TELLING When you tell a student exactly what to do, and he does it, you're teaching — transferring tried-and-true neural patterns from your working brain into your student's fledgling brain. So you tell the student over and over exactly what you want him to know and do; and before long you find him saying, without prompting, "Alright already! I've got it." This is teaching. Asking a student to solve problems that he hasn't seen before is not teaching; it's testing. Asking him to hypothesize about future results is not teaching, it's testing. In fact, the whole so-called "Socratic Method" is not teaching; it's testing. And when you use such techniques, you're essentially asking the student to "reinvent the wheel" — to intuitively come up with something that you already know. Why not let him in on the secret? So when you're teaching Plain English programming, don't ask your students to solve problems, or guess what will happen if this or that code is run — Tell them. Show them. Let them type it in (so it will enter their brains through their hands as well as their eyes and ears), and let them run the programs they've entered (for the fun of it); but don't ask them to "come up with" what's already in your head: hand it to them on a silver platter. Teaching is telling. If a student wants to experiment on his own, that's fine. But don't hand out an assignment unless the answer is provided and the student is told to study and ask questions about the answer (not try to reinvent it on his own). A student who is typing in a correct solution is being taught; a student who is stumbling along making mistakes until he stumbles on the answer is just stumbling. Teaching is telling. Et voila!
